#### Problem 1 (5.11)

Consider the following argument:
"We know that the sum of independent Poisson random variables follows a Poisson distribution with a parameter that is the sum of the parameters of the summands. In particular, if $n$ independent Poisson RVs, each with parameter $n^{-1}$, are summed, the sum has a Poisson distribution with parameter $1$. The CLT says that as $n \rightarrow \infty$, the distribution of the sum tends to a normal distribution, but the Poisson with parameter $1$ is not normal."

#### Problem 3 (6.1)

If $Z \sim N(0,1)$ and $U \sim \chi^2_{n}$ are independent, then 
$$T = \frac{Z}{\sqrt{U/n}} \sim t_{(n)}.$$ 
Prove that the density function of the $t$ distribution with $n$ degrees of freedom is 
$$f(t) = \frac{\Gamma[(n+1)/2]}{\sqrt{n\pi}\Gamma(n/2)} \left( 1 + \frac{t^2}{n} \right)^{-(n+1)/2}.$$
